def: The periodic table classifies elements into metals, metalloids, and nonmetals based on their physical and chemical properties.
An isotope ('same place'...on per.table) is a version of an element with the same number of protons but a different number of neutrons, resulting in a different atomic mass.
An ion ('go'...since move towards electrodes) is an atom or molecule that has gained or lost electrons, giving it a net electric charge.
The smallest unit of matter that retains the identity of an element, composed of protons, neutrons, and electrons.
A pure substance made of only one kind of atom, defined by its number of protons.
A substance formed when atoms of two or more different elements chemically bond together.
An ancient Greek philosopher who proposed that matter is composed of indivisible particles called atomos, meaning uncuttable.
A scientist who in 1808 proposed the first modern atomic theory, defining atoms as the fundamental units of elements.

A theory stating that elements are made of atoms, atoms of the same element are identical, compounds form from different atoms, and chemical reactions rearrange atoms without creating or destroying them.
Proposed by Joseph Proust, this law states that a given compound always contains the same elements in the same proportion by mass.
When two elements form more than one compound, the masses that combine do so in ratios of small whole numbers.
A principle stating that matter cannot be created or destroyed in a chemical reaction.
The emission and transmission of energy through space in the form of waves or particles.
Particles smaller than atoms, such as electrons, discovered through studies of radiation and electrical discharge in gases.
A sealed glass tube in which electrons travel from a negative electrode (cathode) to a positive electrode (anode) when voltage is applied.
The negatively charged electrode in a cathode ray tube that emits electrons.
The positively charged electrode in a cathode ray tube that attracts electrons.
A physicist who measured the charge-to-mass ratio of the electron using cathode ray experiments, showing electrons are universal subatomic particles.
A value describing how strongly a charged particle responds to electric or magnetic forces relative to its mass.
A physicist who measured the charge of a single electron using the oil-drop experiment, enabling calculation of the electron’s mass.
